 .highlight pre  .mi { color: #666666 } /* Literal.Number.Integer */
 .highlight pre  .mo { color: #666666 } /* Literal.Number.Oct */
 .highlight pre  .sa { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Affix */
 .highlight pre  .sb { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Backtick */
 .highlight pre  .sc { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Char */
 .highlight pre  .dl { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Delimiter */
 .highlight pre  .sd { color: #BA2121; font-style: italic } /* Literal.String.Doc */
 .highlight pre  .s2 { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Double */
 .highlight pre  .se { color: #AA5D1F; font-weight: bold } /* Literal.String.Escape */
 .highlight pre  .sh { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Heredoc */
 .highlight pre  .si { color: #A45A77; font-weight: bold } /* Literal.String.Interpol */
 .highlight pre  .sx { color: #008000 } /* Literal.String.Other */
 .highlight pre  .sr { color: #A45A77 } /* Literal.String.Regex */
 .highlight pre  .s1 { color: #BA2121 } /* Literal.String.Single */
 .highlight pre  .ss { color: #19177C } /* Literal.String.Symbol */
 .highlight pre  .bp { color: #008000 } /* Name.Builtin.Pseudo */
 .highlight pre  .fm { color: #0000FF } /* Name.Function.Magic */
 .highlight pre  .vc { color: #19177C } /* Name.Variable.Class */
 .highlight pre  .vg { color: #19177C } /* Name.Variable.Global */
 .highlight pre  .vi { color: #19177C } /* Name.Variable.Instance */
 .highlight pre  .vm { color: #19177C } /* Name.Variable.Magic */
 .highlight pre  .il { color: #666666 } /* Literal.Number.Integer.Long */</style><div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<h2 id="Where-we-left-off">Where we left off<a class="anchor-link" href="#Where-we-left-off">¶</a></h2><p>Last post, we explored using <a href="https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.pipeline.Pipeline.html#sklearn.pipeline.Pipeline">Pipelines</a> and <a href="https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.model_selection.GridSearchCV.html?highlight=gridsearchcv#sklearn.model_selection.GridSearchCV">GridSearchCV</a> for training our models. The quick refresher is that <code>GridSearchCV</code> combines <a href="https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~schneide/tut5/node42.html">Cross-Validation</a> (CV), a mechanism to test <a href="https://developers.google.com/machine-learning/crash-course/generalization/video-lecture#:~:text=Generalization%20refers%20to%20your%20model's,model%20is%20good%20or%20not.">how well models generalise to data they have not seen before</a>, with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperparameter_optimization#Grid_search">Grid Search</a> (aka "Parameter Sweep"), a way to check which <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperparameter_(machine_learning">hyperparameters</a>) yield the best performance. <code>Pipelines</code> are (IMO) not nearly as popular as they should be, as these provide an execution plan that gets followed by the <code>GridSearchCV</code> object. This means that, not only can you prevent leakage when doing feature scaling, but you can <em>even let the model decide if it should scale features at all</em>!</p>
<p>Combining these approaches will give you confidence that (given the algorithm, data, hyperparameters and processes you tested) you have picked the optimal model. So what's the problem? Well one fairly large problem is that we don't even know if the algorithm we picked is any good in the first place! For instance, your data clearly exhibits strong periodicity, but your algorithm is not flexible enough to capture it.</p>
<p>Unfortunately the CV process on its own cannot tell you this; you pick a metric to optimize and it will pick the hyperparameters that did the best, but it cannot tell you if it was "good". Adding more hyperparameters to test or even including multiple algorithms within the Pipeline/GridSearchCV object can help reduce the risk, but it does increase the run time substantially AND you still don't know if the performance is "good enough".</p>
<p>A good, principled solution in practice is to establish a baseline of performance and analyze the "<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bias%E2%80%93variance_tradeoff">Bias-Variance Trade-off</a>" with <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_curve_(machine_learning">Learning Curves</a>). A baseline can provide you with a reference as to how well your more advanced approaches are actually improving the problems, while the Learning Curves can help you assess which regime (e.g. High Bias, High Variance) your model is currently in. There are some specific things to look at depending on if you are performing Regression or Classification, so we'll start with a <strong>Regression</strong> example, before moving on to a Classification example (probably in another post).</p>
<h2 id="Regression-Example">Regression Example<a class="anchor-link" href="#Regression-Example">¶</a></h2><p>We'll get started using a Regression example.  In this case, we will generate some 2D data using numpy.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [1]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># Creating some data for the example.  In this case we'll simulate some periodic data.  </span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">numpy</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">np</span>
<span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.pyplot</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">plt</span>
<span class="c1"># Set the Random Seed!</span>
<span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">seed</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">1234</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Create a function to make test and training data </span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">make_data</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">linspace_ranges</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">num_samples</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">150</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">X</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="n">linspace_ranges</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">]</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">linspace_ranges</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">])</span> <span class="o">*</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random_sample</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_samples</span><span class="p">)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">linspace_ranges</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">]</span>
    <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="o">/</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reshape</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,)</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="mf">0.1</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">y</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">random</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">normal</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">X</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reshape</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span>

<span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">make_data</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_test</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">make_data</span> <span class="p">((</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="mi">30</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1">#View the data</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">figure</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[1]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.collections.PathCollection at 0x7fb041550490></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The plot shows the training data in blue and the test data red.</p>
<h3 id="Establishing-Baselines">Establishing Baselines<a class="anchor-link" href="#Establishing-Baselines">¶</a></h3><p>It is a common trap in modeling to focus only on the outcome metrics and when the outcomes <em>seem</em> good, we stop. But what if we had additional context for performance via a baseline?  Consider the following example: <strong>Model A</strong> is trying to classify people into two groups and has an accuracy of 95% while <strong>Model B</strong> is also trying to classify objects into several types and has an accuracy of 65%. Though the tasks are different, which model sounds better? Nearly everyone you ask would select Model A because 95% > 65%. But what if you found out that just guessing the most common group of people would give you an accuracy of 99%? Conversely, what if guessing the most common object type only gives you an accuracy of 12%? Would you still pick Model A?</p>
<p>So-called "<a href="https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.dummy.DummyRegressor.html#sklearn.dummy.DummyRegressor">Dummy Regressors</a>"/"<a href="https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.dummy.DummyClassifier.html">Dummy Classifiers</a>, simple models and pre-existing results provide practitioners with valuable context for model performance.</p>
<p>In this case, we'll use a Dummy Regressor predicting the median value and basic Linear Regression model. Both models are quite generic and neither is particularly advanced, but I personally always start a project doing something similar. Not only does this provide me a good baseline to compare against, but comparing these two approaches can possibly inform me about some structure to the data I should consider when fitting better models.</p>
<p>We'll generate the models and evaluate them both on the training set and testing set. And before we run the models, knowing what you know of our basic plot, you should ask yourself "<strong>Which if any of these estimators may perform well?  Why?</strong>"</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [2]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.dummy</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">DummyRegressor</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.linear_model</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">LinearRegression</span>

<span class="c1"># There are several possible regressor strategies; I just picked the Median for fun.</span>
<span class="n">dummy_reg</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">DummyRegressor</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">strategy</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'median'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="c1"># Fit a generic Linear Regressor with no bells or whistles.</span>
<span class="n">simple_reg</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">LinearRegression</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="c1"># Fit the dummy and simple regression models</span>
<span class="n">dummy_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">simple_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Predict both Training and Test data for both models</span>
<span class="n">dummy_reg_train_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">simple_reg_train_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">simple_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">dummy_reg_test_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">simple_reg_test_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">simple_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>We can now pick several metrics to score the results with, such as Explained Variance, RMSE, R^2, etc...,. For this case, we'll use Mean Absolute Error, Root Mean Square Error and R^2.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [3]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.metrics</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">r2_score</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the Dummy Regressor during Training, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the Dummy Regressor during Test, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'*'</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'*'</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the OLS model during Training, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">simple_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">simple_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">simple_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the OLS model during Test, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">simple_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">simple_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">simple_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>For the Dummy Regressor during Training, the MAE was 1.52, RMSE was 2.15 and R2 was -0.04
For the Dummy Regressor during Test, the MAE was 1.45, RMSE was 2.16 and R2 was -0.03
**************************************************
**************************************************
For the OLS model during Training, the MAE was 1.12, RMSE was 1.41 and R2 was 0.55
For the OLS model during Test, the MAE was 1.26, RMSE was 1.54 and R2 was 0.48
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Without even looking at the data, we can make a few observations.</p>
<ol>
<li>The Dummy Regressor isn't too great (R^2 is basically zero), but it was consistent across the testing and training data, which does imply both sets could have been drawn from the same distribution.</li>
<li>The Linear Regressor did okay; the R^2 is around 0.5 and we see the MAE and RMSE declined compared to the Dummy. Additionally, the values were reasonably stable between test and training.  </li>
</ol>
<p>Since this is a simple 2D example, we can actually plot the data and get a visual confirmation of the results:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [5]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">import</span> <span class="nn">matplotlib.lines</span> <span class="k">as</span> <span class="nn">mlines</span>
<span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">dummy_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'m-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Dummy - Train'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">simple_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'b-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Simple - Train'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Actuals vs Predictions'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'upper left'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[5]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x7fb011436ce0></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>So let's start fitting some more advanced models that can deal with the extra curvature. We'll do that in this case with polynomial regression.</p>
<p><strong>NOTE:</strong> There are many other ways of doing this (and I prefer some over this), but I'll stick with using <code>sklearn's</code> <code>PolynomialFeatures</code> class as a way to stay entirely within <code>sklearn's</code> universe.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [6]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.preprocessing</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">PolynomialFeatures</span>
<span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.pipeline</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">make_pipeline</span>

<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">PolynomialRegression</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">degree</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="k">return</span> <span class="n">make_pipeline</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">PolynomialFeatures</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">degree</span><span class="p">),</span>
                         <span class="n">LinearRegression</span><span class="p">())</span>

<span class="n">deg2_reg</span>  <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">PolynomialRegression</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">deg4_reg</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">PolynomialRegression</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">deg10_reg</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">PolynomialRegression</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">deg2_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">deg4_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">deg10_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fit</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="c1"># Predict both Training and Test data for both models</span>
<span class="n">deg2_reg_train_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">deg4_reg_train_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">deg10_reg_train_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">)</span>

<span class="n">deg2_reg_test_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">deg4_reg_test_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">deg10_reg_test_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now it's possible all of these models may do a decent job on the data, though one is probably going to underfit (degree 2) and one is likely to overfit (degree 10).</p>
<p>Let's run our metrics again and then we'll look at some plots.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [7]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the 2nd-Degree Regressor during Training, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the 2nd-Degree Regressor during Test, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'*'</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'*'</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the 4th-Degree Regressor during Training, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the 4th-Degree Regressor during Test, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'*'</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'*'</span><span class="o">*</span><span class="mi">50</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the 10th-Degree Regressor during Training, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
<span class="nb">print</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'For the 10th-Degree Regressor during Test, the MAE was </span><span class="si">{0:.2f}</span><span class="s1">, RMSE was </span><span class="si">{1:.2f}</span><span class="s1"> and R2 was </span><span class="si">{2:.2f}</span><span class="s1">'</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">format</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">mean_absolute_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">mean_squared_error</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">squared</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="kc">False</span><span class="p">),</span>
                                                                                               <span class="n">r2_score</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg_test_pred</span><span class="p">)</span>
                                                                                               <span class="p">))</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>


<div class="output_subarea output_stream output_stdout output_text">
<pre>For the 2nd-Degree Regressor during Training, the MAE was 0.89, RMSE was 1.12 and R2 was 0.72
For the 2nd-Degree Regressor during Test, the MAE was 1.00, RMSE was 1.21 and R2 was 0.67
**************************************************
**************************************************
For the 4th-Degree Regressor during Training, the MAE was 0.79, RMSE was 0.98 and R2 was 0.78
For the 4th-Degree Regressor during Test, the MAE was 0.70, RMSE was 0.95 and R2 was 0.80
**************************************************
**************************************************
For the 10th-Degree Regressor during Training, the MAE was 0.78, RMSE was 0.97 and R2 was 0.79
For the 10th-Degree Regressor during Test, the MAE was 0.76, RMSE was 1.00 and R2 was 0.78
</pre>
</div>
</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>The results confirmed our hunches:</p>
<ol>
<li>The second-degree polynomial did better than the simple regression model but did not perform as well on the test data.  </li>
<li>The fourth-degree polynomial had the strongest performance and generalized well to the test data.  </li>
<li>The 10th degree polynomial also performed well, basically matching the 4th degree polynomial.   </li>
</ol>
<p>Based solely on this evidence, we would select the 4th degree polynomial as our function since it had the best performance.</p>
<p><strong>NOTE:</strong> Even if the metrics with the 4th and 10th degree polynomial were swapped, we'd still likely take the 4th degree polynomial since the performance was comparable and you should also choose the simplest model when there are ties (the <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Occam's_razor">Principle of Parsimony/Occam's Razor</a>).</p>
<p>Since we have a nice 2D case, we can also look at the plots to confirm the metrics:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [9]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="c1"># We need to create a sorted list of indices to make the plots look nice (remember our x-Axis are randomly distributed)</span>
<span class="n">indices_to_order_by</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">X_train</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">reshape</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,)</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">argsort</span><span class="p">()</span>

<span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylim</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">12</span><span class="p">))</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">scatter</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_test</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'r'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">simple_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'b-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'Simple - Train'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">indices_to_order_by</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">deg2_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">indices_to_order_by</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="s1">'r-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'2nd Deg - Train'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">indices_to_order_by</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">deg4_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">indices_to_order_by</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="s1">'g-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'4th Deg - Train'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">indices_to_order_by</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="n">deg10_reg_train_pred</span><span class="p">[</span><span class="n">indices_to_order_by</span><span class="p">],</span> <span class="s1">'k-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'10th Deg - Train'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">linewidth</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">3</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="s1">'Actuals vs Predictions'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'upper left'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt output_prompt">Out[9]:</div>




<div class="output_text output_subarea output_execute_result">
<pre><matplotlib.legend.Legend at 0x7fb0114371f0></pre>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>

<img src="data:image/png;base64,"
>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>In this clearly contrived case, our visual inspection of the data and using our basic metrics makes it very clear which model is optimal. But what if we weren't in a 2D case? How can we quantify whether or not our models have high bias or high variance? Can we learn if adding more data is beneficial? The answer is Yes! We will use <a href="https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/learning_curve.html#learning-curve">Learning Curves</a>!</p>
<h3 id="Learning-Curves)"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_curve_(machine_learning">Learning Curves</a>)<a class="anchor-link" href="#Learning-Curves)">¶</a></h3><p>As mentioned earlier, learning curves give the practitioner the ability to quickly assess the bias and variance of the model. In addition, we can learn if more data is needed to improve the model.</p>
<p>There are several versions of this, the most common plotting errors on the y-axis as samples increase on the x-axis for Training and Validation data (i.e. when using the preferred "Train, Validate, Split" approach). However, I really like <a href="https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.model_selection.learning_curve.html#sklearn.model_selection.learning_curve">scikit's implementation</a>. In this case, the "Out-of-Sample" is handled via a Cross-Validation operator.</p>
<p><a href="https://scikit-learn.org/stable/auto_examples/model_selection/plot_learning_curve.html">scikit has great code</a> to simultaneously plot learning curves with run times as well. To be clear and give credit where credit is due, I lifted the <ins>core part</ins> of this function and put it below. I didn't stick with their code (again, it's excellent) for a few reasons:</p>
<ol>
<li>I wanted to be able to change the scoring function; their code leaves it to the default scorer of your estimator.</li>
<li>In regression, sklearn likes to find the optimal solution by finding the minimum of a function (why you see "neg_" in front of most regression scorers) and I thought it would be more intuitive for now to see functions being minimized.</li>
<li>This was a great chance to pass a custom scorer through.</li>
</ol>
<p>I've stripped out all of the timing functionality and some of the other bells and whistles, but the core functionality is the above code. Later, if you want to continue playing around with learning curves, I would definitely recommend using their code in the link.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [10]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="kn">from</span> <span class="nn">sklearn.model_selection</span> <span class="kn">import</span> <span class="n">learning_curve</span>

<span class="c1"># Making a custom scorer for a couple reasons.</span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">make_rmse</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">estimator</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="n">y_pred</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">estimator</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">predict</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">X</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="k">return</span>  <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">sqrt</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">((</span><span class="n">y_pred</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">)</span><span class="o">**</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">))</span>

<span class="c1"># Creating a modified plotting function to better handle the custom solver</span>
<span class="k">def</span> <span class="nf">lc_plots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">estimator</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">title</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ylims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">train_size_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.1</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">cv_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">scoring_method</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'custom'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_axis_label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">):</span>
    <span class="c1"># Handle the customer scorer, or some other function before defaulting to the defaults</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">scoring_method</span> <span class="o">==</span> <span class="s1">'custom'</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">scoring_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">make_rmse</span>
    <span class="k">elif</span> <span class="n">scoring_method</span> <span class="ow">is</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">scoring_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">scoring_method</span>
    <span class="k">else</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">scoring_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="kc">None</span>
        
    <span class="c1"># Create Learning Curve values</span>
    <span class="n">num_samples</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">train_vals</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cv_vals</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">learning_curve</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">estimator</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y</span><span class="p">,</span> 
                                                      <span class="n">train_sizes</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">array</span><span class="p">([</span><span class="n">x</span> <span class="k">for</span> <span class="n">x</span> <span class="ow">in</span> <span class="n">train_size_list</span><span class="p">]),</span> 
                                                      <span class="n">cv</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">cv_func</span><span class="p">,</span>
                                                      <span class="n">n_jobs</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="o">-</span><span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">,</span>
                                                      <span class="n">scoring</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">scoring_func</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="c1"># Make values for plots</span>
    <span class="n">train_scores_mean</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">train_vals</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">train_scores_std</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">train_vals</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">cv_scores_mean</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">mean</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cv_vals</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">cv_scores_std</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">std</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">cv_vals</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">axis</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">1</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">fig</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ax</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">subplots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">figsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">8</span><span class="p">))</span>
    <span class="k">if</span> <span class="n">ylims</span> <span class="ow">is</span> <span class="ow">not</span> <span class="kc">None</span><span class="p">:</span>
        <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">ylim</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">ylims</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fill_between</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_samples</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">train_scores_mean</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">train_scores_std</span><span class="p">,</span>
                         <span class="n">train_scores_mean</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">train_scores_std</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">alpha</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.1</span><span class="p">,</span>
                         <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"r"</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">fill_between</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_samples</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cv_scores_mean</span> <span class="o">-</span> <span class="n">cv_scores_std</span><span class="p">,</span>
                         <span class="n">cv_scores_mean</span> <span class="o">+</span> <span class="n">cv_scores_std</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">alpha</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="mf">0.1</span><span class="p">,</span>
                         <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"g"</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_samples</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">train_scores_mean</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'o-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"r"</span><span class="p">,</span>
                 <span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"Training score"</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">plot</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">num_samples</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">cv_scores_mean</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'o-'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">color</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"g"</span><span class="p">,</span>
                 <span class="n">label</span><span class="o">=</span><span class="s2">"Cross-validation score"</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_title</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">title</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">20</span><span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">yaxis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_label_text</span><span class="p">(</span> <span class="n">y_axis_label</span> <span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">ax</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">xaxis</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">set_label_text</span><span class="p">(</span> <span class="s1">'# of Samples'</span> <span class="p">)</span>
    <span class="n">plt</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">legend</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">loc</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'upper left'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">fontsize</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">14</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Now we can plot an example to see what this looks like. Let's start with the highest-bias learner we have:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [11]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">lc_plots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">dummy_reg</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Dummy Regression'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ylims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">4</span><span class="p">),</span> 
            <span class="n">train_size_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.05</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">cv_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> 
            <span class="n">scoring_method</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'custom'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_axis_label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'RMSE'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This is an excellent example of one of major pathologies of a high bias learner. Specifically:</p>
<ul>
<li>The CV score (green line) is flat as we add data. This implies the learner is not able to learn from increased data</li>
<li>From our earlier work with metrics, we know that some estimators had RMSE's of about 1, so the level both Training and CV have converged to is quite high.</li>
<li>The Training score (red line) degrades quickly (not necessarily a problem) but then becomes flat. It may be increasing slightly, but in general this is indicative of something that is also not evolving with newer data.</li>
</ul>
<p>As a <code>TODO</code> I will try and make some extra graphics that illustrate other potential pathologies. In the meantime, we can examine our four models we created earlier:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [13]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">lc_plots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">simple_reg</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'Simple Regression'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ylims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">),</span> 
            <span class="n">train_size_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.05</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">cv_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> 
            <span class="n">scoring_method</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'custom'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_axis_label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'RMSE'</span><span class="p">)</span>
<span class="n">lc_plots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">deg2_reg</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'2nd Degree Poly'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ylims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">),</span> 
            <span class="n">train_size_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.05</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">cv_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> 
            <span class="n">scoring_method</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'custom'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_axis_label</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'RMSE'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,"
>
</div>

</div>

<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>Both of these models are underfitting (effectively flat CV scores), though they are outperforming the Dummy model as the values are decreasing. Next let's look at our 4th degree model:</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [14]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">lc_plots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">deg4_reg</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'4th Degree Poly'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ylims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">),</span> 
            <span class="n">train_size_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.05</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">cv_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> 
            <span class="n">scoring_method</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'custom'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>This fit looks pretty good:
1) Both lines converge to each other at about the same time and the delta between them is small to nonexistent. 
2) The RMSE is about 1 which is about what we saw in our earlier analysis
3) The two lines being flat after about 40 samples indicates adding more data would not likely improve the fit of the model.</p>
<p>Lastly, let's look at the 10th degree polynomial.</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing code_cell rendered">
<div class="input">
<div class="prompt input_prompt">In [15]:</div>
<div class="inner_cell">
    <div class="input_area">
<div class=" highlight hl-ipython3"><pre><span></span><span class="n">lc_plots</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="n">deg10_reg</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">X_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">y_train</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="s1">'10th Degree Poly'</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="n">ylims</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="p">(</span><span class="mi">0</span><span class="p">,</span><span class="mi">2</span><span class="p">),</span> 
            <span class="n">train_size_list</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="n">np</span><span class="o">.</span><span class="n">linspace</span><span class="p">(</span><span class="mf">0.05</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mf">1.0</span><span class="p">,</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">),</span> <span class="n">cv_func</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="mi">10</span><span class="p">,</span> 
            <span class="n">scoring_method</span> <span class="o">=</span> <span class="s1">'custom'</span><span class="p">)</span>
</pre></div>

    </div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="output_wrapper">
<div class="output">


<div class="output_area">

    <div class="prompt"></div>




<div class="output_png output_subarea ">
<img src="data:image/png;base64,"
>
</div>

</div>

</div>
</div>

</div>
<div class="cell border-box-sizing text_cell rendered"><div class="prompt input_prompt">
</div><div class="inner_cell">
<div class="text_cell_render border-box-sizing rendered_html">
<p>As expected, this is a textbook case of overfitting. In this particular plot, we can diagnose it from:</p>
<ul>
<li>The green line has massive error for small training sizes (the shaded area is based on the standard deviation of the CV folds at that size).  </li>
<li>While the training score has steadily increasing error as training size increases, the CV loss does not decrease in a similar way, which doesn't really start leveling out until much later.</li>
<li>Lastly, note that while the two lines are converging, there is a gap between the two.</li>
</ul>
<p>Another <code>TODO</code> for me will be to add some extra graphics illustrating "overfitting" pathologies.</p>
<p>But that's it! Combining both of our results, we would have concluded the same answer, but with Learning Curves and baseline metrics, would could have made the conclusions without needing to visualize the data. Since we rarely are solving simple 2D or 3D problems, this is a great advantage.</p>
<h3 id="Prediction-Intervals-(Regression-Specific)">Prediction Intervals (Regression Specific)<a class="anchor-link" href="#Prediction-Intervals-(Regression-Specific)">¶</a></h3><p>One last technique that can definitely be used for model validation would be using <a href="https://machinelearningmastery.com/prediction-intervals-for-machine-learning/">prediction intervals</a>. We won't be delving into this in this notebook since it is not necessarily a function you can apply to every ML algorithm.  In sklearn, I'm only familiar with making these intervals with <a href="https://scikit-learn.org/stable/auto_examples/ensemble/plot_gradient_boosting_quantile.html">Gradient Boosting Regressors/Random Forest Regressors</a> and manually doing Linear Regression prediction intervals.</p>
<p>If you are doing one of these methods, it is possible to build prediction intervals and calculating various metrics associated to these (e.g. the proportion of test points within their prediction intervals) as another means to see if the model is generalizing well.</p>
<p><strong>NOTE:</strong> Tree ensembles don't generalize well to inputs it's never seen before!</p>
<p>If you happen to be using a probabilistic framework, you'll be able to do more with your estimates as you'll have a full distribution to query regarding your out-of-sample predictions, but this is something we will cover much later. :)</p>
<h1 id="Summary">Summary<a class="anchor-link" href="#Summary">¶</a></h1><p>We've completed the first part of the <em>Model Validation</em> series!  This focussed on analysis of Regression models and we showed how to quickly construct data-driven baseline metrics. Lastly, we showed a graphical means of assessing high bias or variance in a model using Learning Curves.</p>
<p>In next part, we'll review the topics we've just covered but in a classification setting, as well as discussing confusion matrices and the Receiver Operator Characteristic (ROC) and Area Under the Curve (AUC) metric.</p>
<p>Thanks for stopping by!</p>

</div>
</div>
</div>

    var mathjaxscript = document.createElement('script');
    mathjaxscript.id = 'mathjaxscript_pelican_#%@#$@#';

    mathjaxscript[(window.opera ? "innerHTML" : "text")] =
        "MathJax.Hub.Config({" +
        "    config: ['MMLorHTML.js']," +
        "    TeX: { extensions: ['AMSmath.js','AMSsymbols.js','noErrors.js','noUndefined.js'], equationNumbers: { autoNumber: 'AMS' } }," +
        "    jax: ['input/TeX','input/MathML','output/HTML-CSS']," +
        "    extensions: ['tex2jax.js','mml2jax.js','MathMenu.js','MathZoom.js']," +
        "    displayAlign: 'center'," +
        "    displayIndent: '0em'," +
        "    showMathMenu: true," +
        "    tex2jax: { " +
        "        inlineMath: [ ['$','$'] ], " +
        "        displayMath: [ ['$$','$$'] ]," +
        "        processEscapes: true," +
        "        preview: 'TeX'," +
        "    }, " +
        "    'HTML-CSS': { " +
        " linebreaks: { automatic: true, width: '95% container' }, " +
        "        styles: { '.MathJax_Display, .MathJax .mo, .MathJax .mi, .MathJax .mn': {color: 'black ! important'} }" +
        "    } " +
        "}); ";
    (document.body || document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0]).appendChild(mathjaxscript);
}

entry.title: Introduction to scikit-learn Best Practices
entry.summary: Showing how to integrate gridsearchcv within sklearn pipelines
entry.content:
<style type="text/css">/*!
